by Laura Perkinson

been made available to Hopkins

time. This innovative study,
which has been expanding rapidly
throughout the country in recent
years, has been at Hopkins in the

center for three years, but an official major in the area was approved just last spring. Programs
of study have been introduced on
both the graduate and
undergraduate levels.

department. Without any publicity or advertisement of the program, five undergraduates have
already declared majors in the
field. Carramazza feels that the
new major will be popular among
students because the field offers
"new challenges and new ideas"
and can be approached from a
variety of different angles.

the mind and its processes: it involves a composite of many different areas of science, including

Diversity Workshops
Combat Prejudice
by Li-Yu Huang
Attempting to combat prejudice
and discrimination, student
leaders and professionals affiliated with Hopkins met Sunday
for a six-hour training workshop,
sponsored by the Human Relations and Campus Diversity
Committee.
The training workshop, entitled "A Campus of Difference,"
was a non-profit program put
together especially for college
campuses by the Anti-Defamation
League, an international human
relations agency founded in 1913.
"We heard of this particular
program at a national student activities conference last February
and thought it would be beneficial
for our campus," Director of Student Activities Bill Smedick said.
"We tried to invite student
leaders from different components of the campus—student
council, athletics, housemasters,
etc., as well as professionals.
There have already been some internalized diversity programs
held this semester, but this is the
first one to include a broader
spectrum of groups."
At the training program, the
students participated in discussions and watched cultural
simulation videos before engaging in an action planning session.
"Our purpose for the day is to
talk, to understand, and to be
enlightened," Assistant National
Director of "A Campus of Difference" Kevin Slater said to the
group.

Slater emphasized the need for
promoting an understanding of
diversity and fighting prejudiced
views. "If you want to protect
yourself, you have to protect
everybody else too," Slater said.
"Diversity is about all of us.
We're not trying to make a
homogeneous society. We want
to show that different is
just.. .different—not good, not
bad."
Smedick agreed, saying that the
reason Student Activities solicited
the program was to help "increase awareness of cultural
diversity on campus. This is
something that needs to be done
everywhere, not just at
Hopkins," Smedick said. "We'll
do whatever we can do to achieve
it here."
While there will probably not
be another meeting incorporating
such a broad group of leaders until next year, the newly-formed
Human Relations and Campus
Diversity Committee (HRCD),
led by the Director of Minority
Student Services Dr. Francine
Ashby, will continue meeting this
year.
"We don't expect this
workshop or our committee to
result in sudden institutional
change," HRCD Co-chairman
Wes Woods said. "Our longterm goal is to change people's
attitudes. We want to try to make
people more receptive to other
people's cultures. We want people to stop making assumptions
that status quo is the best thing
and the only right thing."

Norman Cousins Awarded
Albert Schweitzer Prize
by Fariah Khan
President Richardson presented
author Norman Cousins with the
Albert Schweitzer Prize for
Humanitarianism on behalf of the
Alexander von Humboldt Foundation of New York on Thursday,
October 18.
Cousins opened his address to
a large audience in Shriver Hall
by expressing his gratitude and
saying that being connected with
the Schweitzer name involved
"profound honor and tremendous
responsibility. It is also a name
associated with philosophical
thinking and education. But, what
is education, what is it that we
learn in life?"
Cousins said that the main pur-

pose of education was to help an
individual come into "full possession of his/her powers." Cousins
also elaborated on his visit to the
U.S.S.R. and the metamorphosis
of the Soviet Union. He said that
there is danger in the change itself
because political change does not
equate economic change. There
are long lines in front of the foodbank and deep dissatisfaction
among the citizens and it is uncertain whether economic change
will catch up, he explained.
Cousins advocates outside intervention. He says that the U.S.
should encourage American
business to open factories in the
U.S.S.R. instead of giving aid
directly so a free-market
economy can be set up. Other-

wise, the Soviet Union, in its
desperate search for hard currency, may be forced to sell stocks
of weapons to the third world
countries, "which would only
create other Iraqs and trans."
The cold war is ending but its
legacy continues, according to
Cousins. He cited two aspects of
the legacy that persist: weapons
and secrecy. Cousins said that
secrecy is a habit that can destroy
our institutions. For example, the
government's claim is that only
250 troops were killed in Panama
while only two weeks ago,
Cousins said, "60 Minutes"
reported that there were more
than 4,000 casualties and that the
bodies were buried secretly.

Three Hours A Week
Each year brings with it specific concerns and issues, raised
by students and addressed (or not) by the responsible administrative branch and the Hopkins community. Particularly
pressing for students, and troubling for administrators, is
Hopkins' earned reputation as a relentlessly academic school,
without time or space for socializing among students. Last Saturday night the Grad Club hosted its first big dance party of the
year. Two live bands played to a large, enthusiastic student
crowd—an outbreak of that elusive social life and, for that evening, at least, a student gathering place. The bands played from
10:00 p.m. until approximately 1:15 a.m. The evening was successful from a financial standpoint as well as a programming/organizational standpoint.
Apparently, however, some McCoy residents found the noise
from this successful event objectionable. Noise in McCoy has
always been an obstacle for the club and an issue of negotiation between the club, the residents, and Residential Life. Last
year these negotiations led to the cancellation of Thursday night
Funk Nite, volume limits, the addition of sound absorption
panels, and other programming modifications.
This week negotiations were by-passed, and a decree was
handed down: no amplified music, probably for the rest of the
year. The new club management was not given an opportunity
to meet with McCoy residents or to investigate the noise situation themselves. It is not clear how many residents complained. When the club received the first complaint at 10:15 p.m.,
the manager turned down the volume and closed the doors and
windows. No further complaints were received directly by the
club, leading the manager to believe that these steps had offered at least some relief.
Certainly the needs of McCoy residents need to be addressed. The current management of the Grad Club wants very much

to "meet them halfway." The Grad Club is operating from an
already greatly compromised position, given the concessions
made last year, but the managers are willing to bend further
in order to accommodate those with complaints. But the decision was made before any such dialogue could take place.
The Grad Club exists for students and is operated primarily
by students. It fills many gaps in Hopkins life—gaps left by
a lack of on-campus housing and a poor substitute for a student union. This year, with new hours and the addition of coffee to the menu, a broader slice of the student population has
taken advantage of the space and atmosphere. Students meet
for a cozy chat, a cup of coffee, or a break from the fluorescent glare of the library. Student groups schedule meetings
there, avoiding the battle for on-campus space and offering their
members a more casual but still productive atmosphere, with
possibilities for socializing after the meeting.
During the week the club does not sell enough beer, coffee,
or pizza to pay the wages of the student staff. While this does
not mean that the overall benefits to students do not justify the
investment, it makes for a weaker case when confronting a(supposedly) financially strapped administration. However, revenues
from last Saturday indicate that the club could operate in the
black with five quiet nights and one music night each week.
This schedule represents sensitivity to the needs of both the "student population at large" and McCoy residents. Students have
both meeting and social space during the week, and an alternative to fraternity parties and the local bars on the weekend.
All of this can be maintained with only three hours of amplified
music each week. If three hours of music each week, on a
weekend night, with the music off by 1:00 a.m., and the volume
kept below a certain level is not considered a generous compromise, what would be?

With some mediocrity and a
few points of excellence,
Carmen, one of the most popular
and best known operas in the
world, ended its run at the
Baltimore opera last weekend.
First performed in 1875, Carmen
was written by Georges Bizet and
based on the short novel by Prosper Merimee. Although the
opera was shunned by audiences
during the first seven years of
performance, with added music
by Ernest Guiraud, the opera has
become famous.
The story opens in the town of
Seville, Spain, in the middle of
a hot summer. Don Jose, the corporal of the Dragoons and the
protagonist, is in love with his
sweetheart Micaela from his
home town. Micaela is visiting
Jose in Seville and bringing him
news from home. She leaves Jose
for a time, and we are introduced to a seductress, Carmen, a
cigarette girl. Every day during
a break at the factory, the
cigarette girls empty into the
square to flirt with and seduce the
soldiers. The Gypsy Carmen
flirts, airing her philosophy of life
in the famous "L'amour est un
oiseau rebel/c" (love is a wild
bird that can't be tamed).
Carmen, drawn by Jose's apparent indifference to her
feminine wiles, begins her seduction of Jose with this aria.
Jose, although not completely
under Carmen's spell, is
noticeably disturbed. After
Carmen leaves, Micaela returns,
and Jose pledges his love to her,
vowing to marry her. Once
Micaela leaves (this time for her
far away home), Carmen is involved in a fight at the cigarette
factory. Don Jose, under orders
from his superior officer, must
arrest Carmen. While he is

month.

Preventing rape
Stopping assault before it happens
by Kathleen Curry
Imagine yourself leaving leaving a shopping mall late one
December afternoon. Your arms
are full of packages—you've been
doing some holiday shopping.
You notice a van parked next to
your car on the driver's side. It's
getting dark and your car is in a
rather remote corner of the parking lot. How do you feel? What
do you do?
This question of emotional
response and judgment opened
the Brown Bag Lunch Series'
program on sexual assault protection. Sharon Reynolds, representative from the Sexual Assault
Recovery Center and perhaps better known on campus as the
Assistant Director of Residential
Life led the program, offering
valuable tips on self-defense and
protection from sexual assault.
In the parking lot scenario,
Sharon suggested consolidating
packages to allow for a free hand,
holding a key before getting to the
car, and even entering through
the passenger's door and climbing through to the driver's side.
"You may feel a little silly,"
she acknowledged, "but it may
just make the difference and mean
your safety."
Ms. Reynolds emphasized the
importance of remaining aware of
one's surroundings at all times.
She drew an analogy to
automobile safety. "When you're
driving a car, you're constantly
keeping track of who's around
you," she said.
She continued to explain that it
is important to trust your intuitive
reaction to potentially dangerous
situations. If possible, she suggests finding the closest well-lit
and populated area to discourage
attackers.
Equally important in selfdefense strategy is not allowing
oneself to look like an easy target.
"Look like you're in charge,"
she says. "The less vulnerable

you look, the less likely you are
to be a victim."
In addition to looking confident, Ms. Reynolds suggested
that women wear flats instead of
heels, and always keep one hand
free for defense. She cautioned
women on carrying self-defense
apparatus such as mace and handguns, however because they can
easily be used against the victim.
Instead, she recommended selfdefense classes, which teach not
only strategy for physically warding off attackers, but just as importantly how to stay calm in
order to be able to defend oneself
more effectively.
Ms. Reynolds also suggested
practicing drawing attention to
the attack. She explained that
often women are mentally unprepared for an attack and find
themselves unable to scream or
run. Practicing screaming and
planning methods of alerting attention can be vital to selfpreservation.
Ms. Reynolds also acknowledged that in certain circumstances one can only hope to
talk an attacker out of attacking.
"Sometimes you're in a lifethreatening situation," she says.
"The reality is it's better to be
alive. Sometimes you can't fight
back."
During the second half of the
program Ms. Reynolds opened
the floor to discussion. Members
of the audience offered stories
and safety tips. As one woman

In a similar story, Prodey told
of a researcher who hypothesized that students who were impatient and arrogant and who had illegible penmanship were more
likely to become doctors. The
researcher found that these
characteristics, which she termed "Physician's Personality
Disorder," were the result of the
profession, not the cause. Normal
people simply underwent a personality change.•
Similarly, most alcoholics are
otherwise normal people, though
some alcohol abusers do have
character disorders or psychiatric
disorders. Others, particularly
those with an alcoholic parent,
may have a genetic predisposition
to the disease.
But even those predisposed or
at risk for alcoholism are not
necessarily predestined to abuse
alcohol. As Prodey explained,
"If you don't learn denial, you
can't become a drunk." A loss of
control begins the process of
alcohol abuse. Occasional drinks
become repeated drinks, repeated
drinks become a habit, and the
habit becomes an addiction.
As Martin emphasized, the best
ways to prevent the occasional
social drink from developing into a pattern of abuse are education and wellness. "Alcohol has
a place in our society. . . but if
people are going to use alcohol,
there are things they need to
know."
The large majority of people do
drink responsibly. But "by
definition, anybody with a problem has a problem, and that
doesn't necessarily mean
alcoholism. It might mean missing classes, drinking and driving,

boyfriend or girlfriend. . . these

all signify a problem. "You don't
have to be an alcoholic to have
problems."
According to Martin, "alcohol
abuse does not exist in a
vacuum." Problems with alcohol
are often just symptomatic of
underlying problems with selfesteem. This is why, for example, anorexics and bulimics often
become alcoholic.
According to Martin, "It fits in
with our philosophy that alcohol
is only one of the wellness
issues. . . Many other things interact with alcohol. We have tried
not to just look at alcohol in isolation."
Wellness and education are the
two most effective ways of combatting alcoholism. "The better
personal skills we have, the better we feel about ourselves, the
less likely we'll harm ourselves."
This was also the rationale behind
the Wellness fair in the Glass
Pavilion on Wednesday.
The Wellness fair, while emphasizing responsible alcohol use
in accordance with National Col-

legiate Alcohol Awareness Week,
also featured booths for APTT,
the Randallstown High chapter of
SADD,and a variety of substance
abuse programs.
The Faculty and Staff
Assistance program gave out
green baloons while the Hopkins
Hospital Program for Alcohol
and Chemical Dependencies offered a sour ball in exchange for
a correct answer about a question
abut alcohol. Outside, students
could test their alcohol
knowledge on the "Wheel of Information" and win a pack of
pumpkin seeds or condoms.
But though the fair was designed to increase alcohol awareness
through fun events, Martin tried
to downplay the significance of
this week as a major event. "We
didn't want a glitz and glitter
thing on just this one week," she
commented. Hopkins instead emphasizes Wellness throughout the
year, as seen, for example, in the
Brown Bag Lunch series.
Martin also blamed society for
much of the low self esteem

which can cause alcohol abuse.
She believes that society creates
the belief that there is a product
for every need: to make you feel
good, to make you attractive to
the opposite sex, to make you
popular. When people can't obtain
the happy ideal promoted by the
products, they become depressed and often turn to alcohol or
other substances to make them
feel better.
This societal influence made
Martin's task that much more difficult. "My job is to promote
wellness," she said, "and this fits
into a larger scheme of things. It's
real difficult to tight something
that's so widely entrenched in our
society. We're talking about a
societal issue here."

people about responsible alcohol
use is an uphill fight, but she
believes that it can—and will—

descision to drink—within the
law. But if they're • going to
choose to drink, these are the
things they need to know."

Saturday, October 20 marked
the fifteenth annual VarsityAlumni lacrosse game. The annual event pits the current varsity squad against past Hopkins
lacrosse players. The game is an
opportunity for current players to
meet some of the greats that contributed to the rich Hopkins
lacrosse tradition, the former
players to meet the future of
Hopkins lacrosse and many campus freshmen to get their first
taste of the unofficial state sport.
This year the event was dedicated
to the memories of Henry A. Ciccarone, Sr. ('62) and Fred B.
Smith, Jr. ('50).
The alumni squad featured four
current U.S. National Team
membrs, one alternate, current
indoor league players and a cast
of former All-Americnas including six alumni from the sixties. In a break from the past,
John Krumenacker ('85) coached the alumni team rather than the
current varsity coach. To add
some humor to the evenings
festivities, Dr. Roger Blumenthal
('81) worked as public address
announcer.
Considering the quality of the
alumni team, the varsity squad is
lucky that the alumni did not have
the opportunity to practice
together. As should be expected,
the varsity team won going away,
12-5. However, the score was insignificant to most concerned.
According to game organizer,
Patrick Russell ('89), the game
was intended for, and played, as
fun for all.
Freshman attaclunan Brian Piccola opened the scoring fifteen
seconds into the game. From the
right side Piccola unleashed a
bullet and beat world team goalie
Larry Quinn ('85). The alumni
looked like they might actually be
competitive as assistant coach Joe
Cowan ('69) scored on a spectacular behind-the-head shot 4a
minute later. The varsity team
proceeded to increase their lead
with seven consecutive goals until
Jeff Ihm ('89) scored late in the

first half, making it R-2. Senior
Mark Dressel and sophomore
Brian Tobin added two more
goals just seventeen seconds apart
to give the varsity a 10-2 halftime
lead.
Once the score had gotten out
of hand, Blumenthal took it upon
himself to entertain the crowd.
When the Offitt brothers took
positions at midfield on a second
half faceoff, Blumenthal pointed
out "another brother pair of midfielders not to be confused with
the Gaits." A look down the
alumni roster revealed three pairs
of brothers playing together (Offitt, Ciccarone, Wilkens), two
playing against brothers currently on the team (Dressel, Kelly)
and a father-son combination (Attackman Mike and honorary
Coach Bill Morrill).
In perhaps the most intriguing
and long awaited matchup, assistant coach Dennis Townsend
('67) defended against his son,
sophomore David. This was not
the only surprise as All-World
defenseman Dave Pietramala forsook his long pole for an attack
stick while former crease attackman Jay Clarke took up a
position at crease defense. While
Clarke managed a couple of stick
checks, Petro was less successful.
Pietramala, who said he was tuning up for the upcoming indoor
season, was stripped twice by
freshman defender Carmen
Cavolo.
The game provided head coach
Tony Seaman with another opportunity to view his new system
at work. The team seems to adjust with each passing day.
Although not playing against a
"team," the Blue Jays appeared
more confident at both ends of the
field. Defensively, the squad
looked more comfortable with the
variations of a zone employed by
Seaman. Offensively Hopkins
looked like a different team from
the one that played Towson in the

The varsity players were passing
the way one would expect AllAmericans to pass, scooping
loose balls and scoring fifteen

Diversity Workshops
Combat Prejudice
by Li-Yu Huang
Attempting to combat prejudice
and discrimination, student
leaders and professionals affiliated with Hopkins met Sunday
for a six-hour training workshop,
sponsored by the Human Relations and Campus Diversity
Committee.
The training workshop, entitled "A Campus of Difference,"
was a non-profit program put
together especially for college
campuses by the Anti-Defamation
League, an international human
relations agency founded in 1913.
"We heard of this particular
program at a national student activities conference last February
and thought it would be beneficial
for our campus," Director of Student Activities Bill Smedick said.
"We tried to invite student
leaders from different components of the campus—student
council, athletics, housemasters,
etc., as well as professionals.
There have already been some internalized diversity programs
held this semester, but this is the
first one to include a broader
spectrum of groups."
At the training program, the
students participated in discussions and watched cultural
simulation videos before engaging in an action planning session.
"Our purpose for the day is to
talk, to understand, and to be
enlightened," Assistant National
Director of "A Campus of Difference" Kevin Slater said to the
group.

Slater emphasized the need for
promoting an understanding of
diversity and fighting prejudiced
views. "If you want to protect
yourself, you have to protect
everybody else too," Slater said.
"Diversity is about all of us.
We're not trying to make a
homogeneous society. We want
to show that different is
just.. .different—not good, not
bad."
Smedick agreed, saying that the
reason Student Activities solicited
the program was to help "increase awareness of cultural
diversity on campus. This is
something that needs to be done
everywhere, not just at
Hopkins," Smedick said. "We'll
do whatever we can do to achieve
it here."
While there will probably not
be another meeting incorporating
such a broad group of leaders until next year, the newly-formed
Human Relations and Campus
Diversity Committee (HRCD),
led by the Director of Minority
Student Services Dr. Francine
Ashby, will continue meeting this
year.
"We don't expect this
workshop or our committee to
result in sudden institutional
change," HRCD Co-chairman
Wes Woods said. "Our longterm goal is to change people's
attitudes. We want to try to make
people more receptive to other
people's cultures. We want people to stop making assumptions
that status quo is the best thing
and the only right thing."

Apparently, however, some McCoy residents found the noise
from this successful event objectionable. Noise in McCoy has
always been an obstacle for the club and an issue of negotiation between the club, the residents, and Residential Life. Last
year these negotiations led to the cancellation of Thursday night
Funk Nite, volume limits, the addition of sound absorption
panels, and other programming modifications.
This week negotiations were by-passed, and a decree was
handed down: no amplified music, probably for the rest of the
year. The new club management was not given an opportunity
to meet with McCoy residents or to investigate the noise situation themselves. It is not clear how many residents complained. When the club received the first complaint at 10:15 p.m.,
the manager turned down the volume and closed the doors and
windows. No further complaints were received directly by the
club, leading the manager to believe that these steps had offered at least some relief.
Certainly the needs of McCoy residents need to be addressed. The current management of the Grad Club wants very much

to "meet them halfway." The Grad Club is operating from an
already greatly compromised position, given the concessions
made last year, but the managers are willing to bend further
in order to accommodate those with complaints. But the decision was made before any such dialogue could take place.
The Grad Club exists for students and is operated primarily
by students. It fills many gaps in Hopkins life—gaps left by
a lack of on-campus housing and a poor substitute for a student union. This year, with new hours and the addition of coffee to the menu, a broader slice of the student population has
taken advantage of the space and atmosphere. Students meet
for a cozy chat, a cup of coffee, or a break from the fluorescent glare of the library. Student groups schedule meetings
there, avoiding the battle for on-campus space and offering their
members a more casual but still productive atmosphere, with
possibilities for socializing after the meeting.
During the week the club does not sell enough beer, coffee,
or pizza to pay the wages of the student staff. While this does
not mean that the overall benefits to students do not justify the
investment, it makes for a weaker case when confronting a(supposedly) financially strapped administration. However, revenues
from last Saturday indicate that the club could operate in the
black with five quiet nights and one music night each week.
This schedule represents sensitivity to the needs of both the "student population at large" and McCoy residents. Students have
both meeting and social space during the week, and an alternative to fraternity parties and the local bars on the weekend.
All of this can be maintained with only three hours of amplified
music each week. If three hours of music each week, on a
weekend night, with the music off by 1:00 a.m., and the volume
kept below a certain level is not considered a generous compromise, what would be?

With some mediocrity and a

First performed in 1875, Carmen
was written by Georges Bizet and
based on the short novel by Prosper Merimee. Although the
opera was shunned by audiences
during the first seven years of
performance, with added music
by Ernest Guiraud, the opera has
become famous.
The story opens in the town of
Seville, Spain, in the middle of
a hot summer. Don Jose, the corporal of the Dragoons and the
protagonist, is in love with his
sweetheart Micaela from his
home town. Micaela is visiting
Jose in Seville and bringing him
news from home. She leaves Jose

cigarette girl. Every day during
a break at the factory, the
cigarette girls empty into the
square to flirt with and seduce the
soldiers. The Gypsy Carmen
flirts, airing her philosophy of life
in the famous "L'amour est un
oiseau rebel/c" (love is a wild
bird that can't be tamed).
Carmen, drawn by Jose's apparent indifference to her

Jose, although not completely

Preventing rape
Stopping assault before it happens
by Kathleen Curry
Imagine yourself leaving leaving a shopping mall late one
December afternoon. Your arms
are full of packages—you've been
doing some holiday shopping.
You notice a van parked next to
your car on the driver's side. It's
getting dark and your car is in a
rather remote corner of the parking lot. How do you feel? What
do you do?
This question of emotional
response and judgment opened
the Brown Bag Lunch Series'
program on sexual assault protection. Sharon Reynolds, representative from the Sexual Assault
Recovery Center and perhaps better known on campus as the
Assistant Director of Residential
Life led the program, offering
valuable tips on self-defense and
protection from sexual assault.
In the parking lot scenario,
Sharon suggested consolidating
packages to allow for a free hand,
holding a key before getting to the
car, and even entering through
the passenger's door and climbing through to the driver's side.
"You may feel a little silly,"
she acknowledged, "but it may
just make the difference and mean
your safety."
Ms. Reynolds emphasized the
importance of remaining aware of
one's surroundings at all times.
She drew an analogy to
automobile safety. "When you're
driving a car, you're constantly
keeping track of who's around
you," she said.
She continued to explain that it
is important to trust your intuitive
reaction to potentially dangerous
situations. If possible, she suggests finding the closest well-lit
and populated area to discourage
attackers.
Equally important in selfdefense strategy is not allowing
oneself to look like an easy target.
"Look like you're in charge,"
she says. "The less vulnerable

you look, the less likely you are
to be a victim."
In addition to looking confident, Ms. Reynolds suggested
that women wear flats instead of
heels, and always keep one hand
free for defense. She cautioned
women on carrying self-defense
apparatus such as mace and handguns, however because they can
easily be used against the victim.
Instead, she recommended selfdefense classes, which teach not
only strategy for physically warding off attackers, but just as importantly how to stay calm in
order to be able to defend oneself
more effectively.
Ms. Reynolds also suggested
practicing drawing attention to
the attack. She explained that
often women are mentally unprepared for an attack and find
themselves unable to scream or
run. Practicing screaming and
planning methods of alerting attention can be vital to selfpreservation.
Ms. Reynolds also acknowledged that in certain circumstances one can only hope to
talk an attacker out of attacking.
"Sometimes you're in a lifethreatening situation," she says.
"The reality is it's better to be
alive. Sometimes you can't fight
back."
During the second half of the
program Ms. Reynolds opened
the floor to discussion. Members
of the audience offered stories
and safety tips. As one woman
noted, "You shouldn't be deceived by the appearance of someone. Chances are he won't
look like a rapist."
A free Women's Self Protection Workshop will be held on
Tuesday, November 6 and Thursday November 8 in the AMR I
Multi-Purpose Room. The session will be led by Sharon Sirkis,
owner and instructor at Universal Kempo Karate. All interested
women students, staff and faculty are invited to attend.

Similarly, most alcoholics are

This was also the rationale behind

The Wellness fair, while emphasizing responsible alcohol use
in accordance with National Col-

Martin also blamed society for
much of the low self esteem

which can cause alcohol abuse.
She believes that society creates

for every need: to make you feel
good, to make you attractive to
the opposite sex, to make you
popular. When people can't obtain
the happy ideal promoted by the
products, they become depressed and often turn to alcohol or
other substances to make them
feel better.
This societal influence made
Martin's task that much more difficult. "My job is to promote
wellness," she said, "and this fits
into a larger scheme of things. It's
real difficult to tight something
that's so widely entrenched in our
society. We're talking about a
societal issue here."
Martin admits that educating
people about responsible alcohol

believes that it can—and will—

America.

the Head of the Charles is the
kind of competition we faced.

teams at any one regular season
event as we did at the Charles,"
said senior captain Kim Roberts.

crews from Vancouver, Toronto,
the University of Wisconsin, and
the University of Washington,
Hopkins fifth place showing was
an outstanding accomplishment
because Hopkins finished ahead
of all other East Coast crews, including those from the perennially dominant Ivy League.

assured a place for themselves in
next year's regatta. All crews that
finish within five percent of the
time of the winning boat are

garnered a spot by finishing
within 3.8 percent of the winning time.

Saturday, October 20 marked
the fifteenth annual VarsityAlumni lacrosse game. The annual event pits the current varsity squad against past Hopkins
lacrosse players. The game is an
opportunity for current players to
meet some of the greats that contributed to the rich Hopkins
lacrosse tradition, the former
players to meet the future of
Hopkins lacrosse and many campus freshmen to get their first
taste of the unofficial state sport.
This year the event was dedicated
to the memories of Henry A. Ciccarone, Sr. ('62) and Fred B.
Smith, Jr. ('50).
The alumni squad featured four
current U.S. National Team
membrs, one alternate, current
indoor league players and a cast
of former All-Americnas including six alumni from the sixties. In a break from the past,
John Krumenacker ('85) coached the alumni team rather than the
current varsity coach. To add
some humor to the evenings
festivities, Dr. Roger Blumenthal
('81) worked as public address
announcer.
Considering the quality of the
alumni team, the varsity squad is
lucky that the alumni did not have
the opportunity to practice
together. As should be expected,
the varsity team won going away,
12-5. However, the score was insignificant to most concerned.
According to game organizer,
Patrick Russell ('89), the game
was intended for, and played, as
fun for all.
Freshman attaclunan Brian Piccola opened the scoring fifteen
seconds into the game. From the
right side Piccola unleashed a
bullet and beat world team goalie
Larry Quinn ('85). The alumni
looked like they might actually be
competitive as assistant coach Joe
Cowan ('69) scored on a spectacular behind-the-head shot 4a
minute later. The varsity team
proceeded to increase their lead
with seven consecutive goals until
Jeff Ihm ('89) scored late in the

first half, making it R-2. Senior
Mark Dressel and sophomore
Brian Tobin added two more
goals just seventeen seconds apart
to give the varsity a 10-2 halftime
lead.
Once the score had gotten out
of hand, Blumenthal took it upon
himself to entertain the crowd.
When the Offitt brothers took
positions at midfield on a second
half faceoff, Blumenthal pointed
out "another brother pair of midfielders not to be confused with
the Gaits." A look down the
alumni roster revealed three pairs
of brothers playing together (Offitt, Ciccarone, Wilkens), two
playing against brothers currently on the team (Dressel, Kelly)
and a father-son combination (Attackman Mike and honorary
Coach Bill Morrill).
In perhaps the most intriguing
and long awaited matchup, assistant coach Dennis Townsend
('67) defended against his son,
sophomore David. This was not
the only surprise as All-World
defenseman Dave Pietramala forsook his long pole for an attack
stick while former crease attackman Jay Clarke took up a
position at crease defense. While
Clarke managed a couple of stick
checks, Petro was less successful.

freshman defender Carmen
Cavolo.

looked more comfortable with the
variations of a zone employed by

looked like a different team from
the one that played Towson in the

the way one would expect AllAmericans to pass, scooping
loose balls and scoring fifteen

My friends all tell me,"Who cares?" My parents say that nobody will know anything about
it. The editors say that it's journalistic suicide. (Except for Sylvia, who thought it was way
cool. Kudos.) Nonetheless, on a complete whim, I present to you this week's quiz, the Eva
"Don't cry for me, Argentina" Peron Quiz.
The rules are same as they always are. Write your name and your answers on a card or a
pad or a ticket, throw it high in the air, and should it make it to the Gatehouse before 5 o'clock
Wednesday, I will change your way of life for a week or maybe two (however long it takes
you to go through a case of beer and ten bucks worth of food). Name me anyone who cares
as much as your loyal QM.
But first a matter of policy. I received a letter this week (mail! I get mail!) from Adrianne
Pierce and Dana Marinacci, two of my entrants from last week, who were concerned about
last week's quiz- results being unfair. To recap, I gave the quiz to one of three tied entrants
(all three of whom had perfect scores after I eliminated my mistake) based on the fact that
he had most fully explained my mistake. In doing this, I was not attempting to slight any of
the other entrants, I was just trying to find some impartial way to pick one of three equal entries. In the future, in the case of a tie, the winner will be decided by random drawing.(No,
that doesn't mean the person whose drawing looks the most random will win.) Also, any entry
discussing Cop Rock will be summarily ignored. Never let it be said that I don't respond well
to criticism. And Adrianne and Dana. . .1 had nothing to do with those twelve anchovy pizzas
that came by your house Thursday.

2. What was her full maiden name?
3. How many siblings did she have, and what were they named?
4. Who was Augustin Magaldi?

6. What was Eva's ambition when arriving in Buenos Aires?
7. Where did she get her first big vocational break?
8. What occurred on June 4, 1943, and how did it affect Eva?
9. What event brought her to meet Juan Peron?
10. What did Eva do to assist Juan Peron's rise to power?
11. How did Eva feel about the middle class of Argentina?
12. What was Eva's tour of Europe named'?
13. Where did it stop?
14. What country refused to invite her?
15. What Argentinian Society broke tradition and did not ask Eva to be president?
16. What organization did Eva form as a result of this?
17. What position did Eva wish to run for in 1951?
18. What prevented her from doing this?
19. What was October 17th?
20. When did Eva die, and what was the suspected cause?
21. Who is Maria Maggi?
22. Where did Eva travel to in 1971?
23. What was remarkable about this trip?
24. What color was Eva's hair'?
25. Where does the quiz title come from, and who wrote it?
Bonus: Nobody around here could remember what kind of money they use in Argentina.
